Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Home Support in Rural-Urban Migration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
While many studies examine people that move to cities from rural communities and how they support family members left behind, this study looks at household life in a community left behind by family members who have moved to cities to become urban workers. As in many such communities, this community has become increasingly integrated into the market economy because of tourism, cash crop production, and improved basic infrastructure. This study examines how economic changes have influenced economic ties between rural family members and urban workers. It also investigates effects on the families left behind, including changes in labor demands and gender relations. Results will be broadly applicable to locations experiencing large scale rural-to-urban migration under similar conditions of economic change. They will be useful to, among others, external analysts trying to make sense of places undergoing economic transformation.

This study uses ethnographic fieldwork, oral-history and key-informant interviews, and archival research to address the following research questions: 1) How do the economic changes influence resource transfers between rural family members and urban workers? 2) What are the labor demands on family members who remain in the village, especially on women who engage in subsistence agriculture, commercialized cash crop production, birthing and raising children, and other types of care work? 3) How are gender relations in the households affected? Findings will illuminate changes to community that can result from economic change and will be useful to policy makers trying to influence change or mitigate its consequences, forecasters seeking to anticipate consequences of economic change, and communities trying to make sense of changes that are occurring.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research examines women’s experience in rural-to-urban migration in China. Different from mainstream research that often focuses on migrants, their work, and lives in the cities, I turn to consider the lives of women who remain in the rural areas and their relationships with migrants. From 2016 to 2018, I conducted fifteen months of ethnographic research in a migrant sending and ethnic Qiang village in Sichuan Province in China. I focused on the group of women who are in their 40s and 50s whose children participate in rural-to-urban labor migration.

My fieldwork is a combination of ethnographic observations, oral-history and key-informant interviews, and archival research. I have produced more than 80 interviews, 520 pages of field notes, 70 pages of analytical memos, and collected dozens of printed documents. Through the research, I find that the trajectories of migration and work of migrants and their relationships with rural families have changed under a labor regime that has become more precarious over time. It has become hard for young migrants to find stable jobs that enable them to financially support their rural families; sometimes, many migrants from the village could not even support their own living in the urban areas. Under these circumstances, rural women in their 40s and 50s found ways to support and even subsidize family members’ labor migration. They did so by earning money from hard work in raising cash crops, giving cash money to migrants to support their living in the cities, gathering resources to help migrants get married, and performing care work (child and elder care) for migrants.

The findings from this research contribute to studies of migration, family, gender, generation, and social change. In particular, the study reveals the gendered ways individuals and families respond to the challenges posed by the spatial inequality of resources and the expansion of precarious labor market. As rural migrants become the main labor force (one third of the total working population) yet disposable workers in the precarious labor regime in China, the women who remain in rural areas also become integrate part and important actors in enabling and supporting rural-to-urban migration. The findings also have strong policy implications, especially for developing countries with large scale rural-to-urban migration. By understanding the role family members who remain in rural areas play in shaping labor migration and modes of resource transfers, policy makers can improve methods and practices in ongoing government initiatives such as anti-poverty and welfare programs.
